SATWord.def: an agreeable way or manner; courtesy; civility: the graceful amenities of society.
an opening, as a hole, slit, crack, gap, etc.
Protest against official policy; dissent
fond of or adapted to luxury or indulgence in sensual pleasures; having luxurious tastes or habits, especially in eating and drinking.
not provident; lacking foresight; incautious; unwary.
Immoral or grossly unfair behavior. (injustice)
prohibiting violation; secure from destruction, violence, infringement, or desecration: an inviolable sanctuary; an inviolable promise.
liable or subject to change or alteration.
beginning to exist or develop: the nascent republic.
a movement of the body expressing deep respect or deferential courtesy, as before a superior; a bow, curtsy, or other similar gesture.
a lofty oration or writing in praise of a person or thing; eulogy.
a wooden framework erected on a post, with holes for securing the head and hands, formerly used to expose an offender to public derision.
a small amount or share.
a presentiment or foreboding.
a descendant or offspring, as a child, plant, or animal.
to make known by open declaration; publish; proclaim formally or put into operation (a law, decree of a court, etc.).
rightness of principle or conduct; moral virtue: the rectitude of her motives.
impatient of control, restraint, or delay, as persons; restless; uneasy.
Angelic
to exist; continue in existence.
Excessively interested in acquiring money or material things
Take or claim (something) for oneself without justification
So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.
Argue or elaborate (a subject) in excessive detail: "they belabored the obvious". Attack or assault (someone) physically or verbally.
characterized by fussy or petulant faultfinding; querulous: carping criticism.
logically connected; consistent: a coherent argument.
to change from a soft or fluid state to a rigid or solid state, as by cooling or freezing: The fat congealed on the top of the soup.
to try to equal or excel; imitate with effort to equal or surpass: to emulate one's father as a concert violinist.
A speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly.
Deliberately avoid using; abstain from: "he appealed to the crowd to eschew violence".
closely or significantly related; relevant; pertinent: Please keep your statements germane to the issue.
(of an appetite or desire) Impossible to satisfy: "an insatiable hunger"
refusing to agree or compromise; uncompromising; inflexible.
calculated to create ill will or resentment or give offense; hateful: invidious remarks.
generous bestowal of gifts.
the act of reconnoitering.
to establish by proof or competent evidence: to substantiate a charge.
inclined to silence; reserved in speech; reluctant to join in conversation.
to be indecisive or evasive to gain time or delay acting.
capable of being held, maintained, or defended, as against attack or dispute: a tenable theory.
to confront boldly: The beggar accosted me for money.
an unfavorable or censorious comment: to make animadversions on someone's conduct.
showing great enthusiasm for or interest in: an avid moviegoer. Synonyms: enthusiastic, ardent, keen; devoted, dedicated; zealous, fanatic. Antonyms: indifferent, apathetic; reluctant.
slightly salt; having a salty or briny flavor.
Swiftness of movement.
departing from the most direct way; circuitous; indirect: a devious course.
A device, action, or opening remark, typically one entailing a degree of risk, that is calculated to gain an advantage.
calm; peaceful; tranquil: halcyon weather.
of or pertaining to actors or acting.
used or adapted for setting property on fire: incendiary bombs.
a large, powerful, or violent whirlpool.
nearsighted: unable to see distant objects clearly
open to view or knowledge; not concealed or secret: overt hostility.
Expressing contempt or disapproval.
conformity to established standards of good or proper behavior or manners.
the violation or profanation of anything sacred or held sacred.
in a prompt or direct manner; immediately; straightaway.
a person who supplicates; petitioner.
a stone, ring, or other object, engraved with figures or characters supposed to possess occult powers and worn as an amulet or charm.
to move with a sinuous or wavelike motion; display a smooth rising-and-falling or side-to-side alternation of movement: The flag undulates in the breeze.
uttered clearly in distinct syllables.
Jump or dance around excitedly: "monkeys leap and cavort in the branches". Apply oneself to sexual or disreputable pursuits: "he spent his nights cavorting with the glitterati".
belief as to the truth of something: to give credence to a claim.
to speak disparagingly of; denounce as faulty or worthless; express censure of: She decried the lack of support for the arts in this country.
to give a false or misleading appearance to; conceal the truth or real nature of: to dissemble one's incompetence in business.
distracted; deeply agitated.
a speech or writing in praise of a person or thing, especially a set oration in honor of a deceased person.
to show clearly; make evident or manifest; prove.
to dig (something buried, especially a dead body) out of the earth; disinter.
ineffective; incompetent; futile: feckless attempts to repair the plumbing.
dark, gloomy, and cheerless.
Wicked or criminal: "the nefarious activities of the organized-crime syndicates".
agreeably pungent or sharp in taste or flavor; pleasantly biting or tart: a piquant aspic.
constituting a beginning; giving origin to something derived or developed; original; elementary: primordial forms of life.
nearness in place; proximity.
not customary or usual; rare: unwonted kindness.
of, pertaining to, or resembling Utopia.
overabundance or superfluity of words, as in writing or speech; wordiness; verbosity.
green with vegetation; covered with growing plants or grass: a verdant oasis.
of a glutinous nature or consistency; sticky; thick; adhesive.
A wasting away of the body or of an organ or part, as from defective nutrition or nerve damage.
Fortification. a projecting portion of a rampart or fortification that forms an irregular pentagon attached at the base to the main work.
agreement between persons, groups, nations, etc.; concurrence in attitudes, feelings, etc.; unanimity; accord: There was complete concord among the delegates.
to bring to a state of perfection; fulfill.
to put out of array or order; throw into disorder.
exigent state or character; urgency.
the part of the wreckage of a ship and its cargo found floating on the water. People or things that have been rejected and are regarded as worthless.
Fast and energetic in a rather wild and uncontrolled way: "a frenetic pace of activity"
to gather slowly and laboriously, bit by bit.
A grumble or complaint.
to imprison; confine.
holding an indicated position, role, office, etc., currently: the incumbent officers of the club.
Fond of or characterized by joking; humorous or playful.
So foolish, unreasonable, or out of place as to be amusing.
sharply caustic or sarcastic, as wit or a speaker; biting.
Irritate or annoy (someone): "I was nettled by her tone".
of or pertaining to money: pecuniary difficulties.
lacking courage or resolution; cowardly; faint-hearted; timid.
lying down; reclining; leaning.
a plan, scheme, or trick for surprising or deceiving an enemy.
Sharpness or keenness of thought, vision, or hearing.
to trace the outline of; sketch or trace in outline; represent pictorially: He delineated the state of Texas on the map with a red pencil.
Morally corrupt
to deprive of force or strength; destroy the vigor of; weaken.
understood by or meant for only the select few who have special knowledge or interest; recondite: poetry full of esoteric allusions.
producing or capable of producing offspring, fruit, vegetation, etc., in abundance; prolific; fruitful: fecund parents; fecund farmland.
an authoritative decree, sanction, or order: a royal fiat. Synonyms: authorization, directive, ruling, mandate, diktat, ukase.
a mere product of mental invention; a fantastic notion: The noises in the attic were just a figment of his imagination.
to gather or deposit in or as if in a granary or other storage place.
to make holy; sanctify; consecrate.
a characteristic, habit, mannerism, or the like, that is peculiar to an individual.
Public shame or disgrace: "the ignominy of being imprisoned".
Lacking interest or excitement; dull. Of this earthly world rather than a heavenly or spiritual one..
a subtle difference or distinction in expression, meaning, response, etc.
presumptuously conceited, overconfident, or proud: a brash, insolent, overweening fellow.
A strong or habitual liking for something or tendency to do something
estimation in the view of others; reputation: persons of good repute.
The use of fallacious arguments, esp. with the intention of deceiving.A fallacious argument.
entailing great expense, as from choice materials, fine work, etc.; costly: a sumptuous residence.
Present, appearing, or found everywhere: "his ubiquitous influence".
utterly hopeless, miserable, humiliating, or wretched: abject poverty.
\the essential nature of things are unknown and unknowable, or that human knowledge is limited to experience.
The state of being involved with others in an illegal activity or wrongdoing
left or deserted, as by the owner or guardian; abandoned: a derelict ship.
A forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something.
a representation or image, especially sculptured, as on a monument.

the quality of being fair or impartial; fairness; impartiality: the equity of Solomon. Synonyms: disinterest, equitableness, impartiality, fair-mindedness, fairness, justness, evenhandedness, objectivity; justice, probity. Antonyms: bias, discrimination, inequity, injustice, partiality, partisanship, prejudice, unfairness, unreasonableness; injustice.
lacking sense, significance, or ideas; silly: inane questions.
an act of indicting.
Impossible to doubt; unquestionable: "an indubitable truth"
stopping or ceasing for a time; alternately ceasing and beginning again: an intermittent pain.
open to discussion or debate; debatable; doubtful: a moot point.
a recurring subject, theme, idea, etc., especially in a literary, artistic, or musical work.
a beginner or novice: He's a neophyte at chess.
keenness of mental perception and understanding; discernment; penetration.
full; complete; entire; absolute; unqualified: plenary powers.
a watch kept over a person, group, etc., especially over a suspect, prisoner, or the like: The suspects were under police surveillance.
of, pertaining to, or inhabiting the woods.
Easily irritated; impatient and somewhat bad-tempered
a literary or artistic burlesque of a serious work or subject, characterized by grotesque or ludicrous incongruity of style, treatment, or subject matter.
